hints_html:
Imagine looking at the trough face on to the equilateral triangle. Choose a coordinate system so that 0 is on the top. Choose a sample point and consider the volume that the small rectangular prism creates.

The following formulas will probably be useful

Volume of a rectangular prism = length x width x height

Imperial Force = Imperial density x volume = gravity x mass = 9.8 x mass

Work = Imperial Force x displacement
hints_latex:
Imagine looking at the trough face on to the equilateral triangle.
Choose a coordinate system so that 0 is on the top. Choose a sample
point and consider the volume that the small rectangular prism creates.
hints_raw:
Imagine looking at the trough face on to the equilateral triangle. Choose a coordinate system so that 0 is on the top. Choose a sample point and consider the volume that the small rectangular prism creates.
The following formulas will probably be useful

 Volume of a rectangular prism = length x width x height

 Imperial Force = Imperial density x volume = gravity x mass = 9.8 x mass

 Work = Imperial Force x displacement
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
Consider the following diagram:

In the picture, we take the perpendicular bisector of the top base and draw the line. This splits our equilateral triangle into two equal parts. The base is \(\sqrt{3}\) and the height is 3 and the other side length is \(2\sqrt{3}\). Choose a sample point say \(\displaystyle x_{i}^{*}\). Let’s call the length of the small triangle point downward l. By similar triangles, we have

\(\displaystyle \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} = \frac{l/2}{3-x_{i}^{*}}\)

and hence

\(\displaystyle l = \frac{2(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}}{3}\)

The volume of the thin prism at this height is

\(\displaystyle V_{i} = l(12)\Delta x = \frac{2(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}}{3} (12\Delta x) = 8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x\)

Next, the force acting on this prism is

\(\displaystyle F_{i} = V_{i}(density) = (62)8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x\)

Lastly, the work done on this piece, noting that the displacement is 1 added to the distance to the bottom of the triangle (which is \(\displaystyle (3-x_{i}^{*})\))

\(\displaystyle W_{i} = F_{i}(displacement) = (62)8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x (4-x_{i}^{*})\)

Summing over all pieces, we have

\(\displaystyle W = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n} W_i = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(62)8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x (4-x_{i}^{*})\)

and this last value is an integral given by

\[\begin{aligned} W &= \int_{0}^{3}(62)8(3-x)\sqrt{3} (4-x) \, dx\\ &= 62(8)\sqrt{3}\int_{0}^{3}(12 - 7x + x^{2}) \, dx\\ &= 62(8)\sqrt{3}(12x - 7x^{2}/2 + x^{3}/3)\bigg|_{0}^{3}\\ &= 62(8)\sqrt{3}(12(3) - 7(3)^{2}/2 + (3)^{3}/3 - 0)\\ &= 62(8)\sqrt{3}(36 - 63/2 + 9)\\ &= 62(4)(27)\sqrt{3}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Consider the following diagram:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH101/April_2005/Math101042005Q5a.jpg}

In the picture, we take the perpendicular bisector of the top base and
draw the line. This splits our equilateral triangle into two equal
parts. The base is $\sqrt{3}$ and the height is 3 and the other side
length is $2\sqrt{3}$. Choose a sample point say
$\displaystyle x_{i}^{*}$. Let's call the length of the small triangle
point downward \emph{l}. By similar triangles, we have

$\displaystyle \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} = \frac{l/2}{3-x_{i}^{*}}$

and hence

$\displaystyle l = \frac{2(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}}{3}$

The volume of the thin prism at this height is

$\displaystyle V_{i} = l(12)\Delta x = \frac{2(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}}{3} (12\Delta x) = 8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x$

Next, the force acting on this prism is

$\displaystyle F_{i} = V_{i}(density) = (62)8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x$

Lastly, the work done on this piece, noting that the displacement is 1
added to the distance to the bottom of the triangle (which is
$\displaystyle (3-x_{i}^{*})$)

$\displaystyle W_{i} = F_{i}(displacement) = (62)8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x (4-x_{i}^{*})$

Summing over all pieces, we have

$\displaystyle W = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n} W_i = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(62)8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x (4-x_{i}^{*})$

and this last value is an integral given by

\begin{align*}
W &= \int_{0}^{3}(62)8(3-x)\sqrt{3} (4-x) \, dx\\
&= 62(8)\sqrt{3}\int_{0}^{3}(12 - 7x + x^{2}) \, dx\\
&= 62(8)\sqrt{3}(12x - 7x^{2}/2 + x^{3}/3)\bigg|_{0}^{3}\\
&= 62(8)\sqrt{3}(12(3) - 7(3)^{2}/2 + (3)^{3}/3 - 0)\\
&= 62(8)\sqrt{3}(36 - 63/2 + 9)\\
&= 62(4)(27)\sqrt{3}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
Consider the following diagram:

[[File:Math101042005Q5a.jpg]]

In the picture, we take the perpendicular bisector of the top base and draw the line. This splits our equilateral triangle into two equal parts. The base is <math> \sqrt{3} </math> and the height is 3 and the other side length is <math> 2\sqrt{3} </math>. Choose a sample point say <math> \displaystyle x_{i}^{*} </math>. Let's call the length of the small triangle point downward ''l''. By similar triangles, we have

<math> \displaystyle
\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} = \frac{l/2}{3-x_{i}^{*}}
</math>

and hence

<math> \displaystyle
l = \frac{2(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}}{3}
</math>

The volume of the thin prism at this height is

<math> \displaystyle V_{i} = l(12)\Delta x = \frac{2(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}}{3} (12\Delta x) = 8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x </math>

Next, the force acting on this prism is

<math> \displaystyle F_{i} = V_{i}(density) = (62)8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x </math>

Lastly, the work done on this piece, noting that the displacement is 1 added to the distance to the bottom of the triangle (which is <math> \displaystyle (3-x_{i}^{*}) </math>)

<math> \displaystyle W_{i} = F_{i}(displacement) = (62)8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x (4-x_{i}^{*}) </math>

Summing over all pieces, we have

<math> \displaystyle W = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n} W_i = \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(62)8(3-x_{i}^{*})\sqrt{3}\Delta x (4-x_{i}^{*}) </math>

and this last value is an integral given by

<math>
\begin{align}
W &= \int_{0}^{3}(62)8(3-x)\sqrt{3} (4-x) \, dx\\
&= 62(8)\sqrt{3}\int_{0}^{3}(12 - 7x + x^{2}) \, dx\\
&= 62(8)\sqrt{3}(12x - 7x^{2}/2 + x^{3}/3)\bigg|_{0}^{3}\\
&= 62(8)\sqrt{3}(12(3) - 7(3)^{2}/2 + (3)^{3}/3 - 0)\\
&= 62(8)\sqrt{3}(36 - 63/2 + 9)\\
&= 62(4)(27)\sqrt{3}
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
A water tank with depth 3 feet is in the shape of the trough depicted below. The bottom edge of the tank is 1 foot above the ground, and the ends of the tank are equilateral triangles of side length \(2\sqrt{3}\) feet; the top of the tank is a rectangle of length 12 feet and width \(2\sqrt{3}\) feet.

(a) The tank is filled with water pumped up from the ground level. How much work is done in filling the tank? Express your answer in foot-pounds, and use the value 62 lb/ft\(^3\) for the density of water. (Note that in the Imperial System, pounds are a unit for force.)

(Do not simplify your answer.)
statement_latex:
A water tank with depth 3 feet is in the shape of the trough depicted
below. The bottom edge of the tank is 1 foot above the ground, and the
ends of the tank are equilateral triangles of side length $2\sqrt{3}$
feet; the top of the tank is a rectangle of length 12 feet and width
$2\sqrt{3}$ feet.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH101/April_2005/Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2005_Question_5_(a)_picture1.png}

(a) The tank is filled with water pumped up from the ground level. How
much work is done in filling the tank? Express your answer in
foot-pounds, and use the value 62 lb/ft$^3$ for the density of water.
(Note that in the Imperial System, pounds are a unit for \emph{force}.)

(Do not simplify your answer.)
statement_raw:
A water tank with depth 3 feet is in the shape of the trough depicted below. The bottom edge of the tank is 1 foot above the ground, and the ends of the tank are equilateral triangles of side length <math>2\sqrt{3}</math> feet; the top of the tank is a rectangle of length 12 feet and width <math>2\sqrt{3}</math> feet.

[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2005_Question_5_(a)_picture1.png|500px]]

(a) The tank is filled with water pumped up from the ground level. How much work is done in filling the tank? Express your answer in foot-pounds, and use the value 62 lb/ft<math>^3</math> for the density of water. (Note that in the Imperial System, pounds are a unit for ''force''.)

(Do not simplify your answer.)
